title: Domus 3 Fake4
description:
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.
Reducing pressure injuries for long-term care — Increasing skin activity and improving blood circulation with alternating pressure.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. However, as proning results in a higher risk of developing pressure injuries (PI), these patients may require 3 more hospital days to treat PI-related complications,3,4 reducing the nurse-to-patient ratio further.5

introductions.title: Access to Controls via Interface
introductions.description: Visual interface with LCD enables quick access to controls such as alternating and zone pressure settings, therapy timer, shoulder lift apparatus, and alarm system settings, simplifying patient care for caregiver across all experience levels.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

title: Pro-care Auto Fake34
description:
Domus 3 combines alternating pressure redistribution and static therapy modes for improving pressure relief care and reducing the caregiver's workload during patient handling procedures, such as dressing changes and repositioning. The weight indicator dial on the pump interface allows quick and easy adjustment to match the support surface pressure firmness to the patient's weight distribution.
Optima Prone's head-to-toe pressure alternation, mechanical apparatus for assisting single-caregiver head repositioning, personalized pressure care with individual air cell deflation, and a unique facial pillow with sculpted ear pocket reduces caregiver workload and risks of pressure injuries, improving patient outcomes.
Optima Auto provides caregivers more control and personalization over air mattress firmness, an elementary air pump interface suitable for all levels of caregivers, and a backup power system for maintaining pressure distribution up to 6 hours. Preventing pressure injuries improves patient outcomes and patient care experience.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: Any recommendations on the number of cells to deflate for each section and for heel relief?
faq.answer: Deflation should follow the location of the patient's vulnerable areas. Our recommendations are:

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

description:

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?

title: Domus 3 Fake63
description:
A staggering 75% of COVID-19 ICU patients require intensive treatments for severe respiratory distress involving mechanical breathing support.1  The 74% mortality rate from severe respiratory distress-associated COVID-19 cases2 overwhelms global healthcare systems, leading to a devastating shortage of resources and imposing complexity and burden on intensive care units and prone positioning therapy management.
Domus 3 combines alternating pressure redistribution and static therapy modes for improving pressure relief care and reducing the caregiver's workload during patient handling procedures, such as dressing changes and repositioning. The weight indicator dial on the pump interface allows quick and easy adjustment to match the support surface pressure firmness to the patient's weight distribution.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

description:

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

title: Pro-care Auto Fake43
description:
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. However, as proning results in a higher risk of developing pressure injuries (PI), these patients may require 3 more hospital days to treat PI-related complications,3,4 reducing the nurse-to-patient ratio further.5
Automating prone shoulder lifting and full-body pressure relief — Reducing workflow complexity and pressure injury risks.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

introductions.description: Visual interface with LCD enables quick access to controls such as alternating and zone pressure settings, therapy timer, shoulder lift apparatus, and alarm system settings, simplifying patient care for caregiver across all experience levels.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

title: Domus Auto Fake80
description:
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.
Optima Auto provides caregivers more control and personalization over air mattress firmness, an elementary air pump interface suitable for all levels of caregivers, and a backup power system for maintaining pressure distribution up to 6 hours. Preventing pressure injuries improves patient outcomes and patient care experience.
Optima Prone's head-to-toe pressure alternation, mechanical apparatus for assisting single-caregiver head repositioning, personalized pressure care with individual air cell deflation, and a unique facial pillow with sculpted ear pocket reduces caregiver workload and risks of pressure injuries, improving patient outcomes.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

title: Pro-care Auto Fake75
description:
Optima Prone's head-to-toe pressure alternation, mechanical apparatus for assisting single-caregiver head repositioning, personalized pressure care with individual air cell deflation, and a unique facial pillow with sculpted ear pocket reduces caregiver workload and risks of pressure injuries, improving patient outcomes.
A staggering 75% of COVID-19 ICU patients require intensive treatments for severe respiratory distress involving mechanical breathing support.1  The 74% mortality rate from severe respiratory distress-associated COVID-19 cases2 overwhelms global healthcare systems, leading to a devastating shortage of resources and imposing complexity and burden on intensive care units and prone positioning therapy management.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. However, as proning results in a higher risk of developing pressure injuries (PI), these patients may require 3 more hospital days to treat PI-related complications,3,4 reducing the nurse-to-patient ratio further.5

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

title: Domus Auto Fake6
description:
Optima Prone's head-to-toe pressure alternation, mechanical apparatus for assisting single-caregiver head repositioning, personalized pressure care with individual air cell deflation, and a unique facial pillow with sculpted ear pocket reduces caregiver workload and risks of pressure injuries, improving patient outcomes.
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.
A staggering 75% of COVID-19 ICU patients require intensive treatments for severe respiratory distress involving mechanical breathing support.1  The 74% mortality rate from severe respiratory distress-associated COVID-19 cases2 overwhelms global healthcare systems, leading to a devastating shortage of resources and imposing complexity and burden on intensive care units and prone positioning therapy management.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

description:

The weight indicator dial on the pump interface allows quick and easy adjustment to match the support surface pressure firmness to the patient's weight distribution.
Alternating pressure redistribution system — Simplify procedure and workload for administering pressure relief care and pressure ulcer prevention.
Reducing pressure injuries for long-term care — Increasing skin activity and improving blood circulation with alternating pressure.

On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: What happens if no power source is available due to, for example, power outages and transportation?
faq.answer: Optima Prone's Transport Mode refers to the combination of:

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

overviews.title: Improve Experience for Compliance
overviews.description: SleepWell allows care providers to provide patients with data-driven suggestions and treatment plans on-demand, increasing the patient's confidence and adherence in the first 90 days, critical for improving long-term therapy compliance.

overviews.title: Reduce Management Complexity
overviews.description: A cloud platform with customizable dashboards, weekly and monthly reports, and filtered overviews allow care providers to remotely monitor treatment processes, assess patient compliance and outcomes, and resolve issues efficiently.

overviews.title: Increase Communication Efficiency
overviews.description: SleepWell unifies language and information sharing between care providers and patients, improving approachability and clarity for treatments and consultations. An easy-to-navigate treatment process is vital for long-term compliance.

overviews.title: Self-Monitor Therapy On-The-Go
overviews.description: SleepWell enables frequent travellers to self-monitor their daily scores and make adjustments with the built-in coaching, making it simple for patients to stay consistent in their sleep therapy and continue improving their therapy outcomes.

overviews.title: Simplify Head Repositioning
overviews.description: Mechanically supporting shoulder lifts while creating space below the patient's chin decreases the caregiver's workload and risk of obstructing airway tubing, allowing the single-caregiver to perform head repositioning safely and efficiently.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

title: Domus 3 Fake3
description:
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. However, as proning results in a higher risk of developing pressure injuries (PI), these patients may require 3 more hospital days to treat PI-related complications,3,4 reducing the nurse-to-patient ratio further.5
Optima Prone's head-to-toe pressure alternation, mechanical apparatus for assisting single-caregiver head repositioning, personalized pressure care with individual air cell deflation, and a unique facial pillow with sculpted ear pocket reduces caregiver workload and risks of pressure injuries, improving patient outcomes.

faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

title: Domus Auto Fake66
description:
A staggering 75% of COVID-19 ICU patients require intensive treatments for severe respiratory distress involving mechanical breathing support.1  The 74% mortality rate from severe respiratory distress-associated COVID-19 cases2 overwhelms global healthcare systems, leading to a devastating shortage of resources and imposing complexity and burden on intensive care units and prone positioning therapy management.
Domus 3 combines alternating pressure redistribution and static therapy modes for improving pressure relief care and reducing the caregiver's workload during patient handling procedures, such as dressing changes and repositioning. The weight indicator dial on the pump interface allows quick and easy adjustment to match the support surface pressure firmness to the patient's weight distribution.
Automating prone shoulder lifting and full-body pressure relief — Reducing workflow complexity and pressure injury risks.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

title: Domus 1 & 2 Fake68
description:
Automating prone shoulder lifting and full-body pressure relief — Reducing workflow complexity and pressure injury risks.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. However, as proning results in a higher risk of developing pressure injuries (PI), these patients may require 3 more hospital days to treat PI-related complications,3,4 reducing the nurse-to-patient ratio further.5
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

title: Pro-care Bariatric Fake56
description:
Automating prone shoulder lifting and full-body pressure relief — Reducing workflow complexity and pressure injury risks.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. Alternating pressure redistribution system — Simplify procedure and workload for administering pressure relief care and pressure ulcer prevention.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: Any recommendations on the number of cells to deflate for each section and for heel relief?
faq.answer: Deflation should follow the location of the patient's vulnerable areas. Our recommendations are:

title: Domus 1 & 2 Fake10
description:
A staggering 75% of COVID-19 ICU patients require intensive treatments for severe respiratory distress involving mechanical breathing support.1  The 74% mortality rate from severe respiratory distress-associated COVID-19 cases2 overwhelms global healthcare systems, leading to a devastating shortage of resources and imposing complexity and burden on intensive care units and prone positioning therapy management.
Domus 3 combines alternating pressure redistribution and static therapy modes for improving pressure relief care and reducing the caregiver's workload during patient handling procedures, such as dressing changes and repositioning. The weight indicator dial on the pump interface allows quick and easy adjustment to match the support surface pressure firmness to the patient's weight distribution.
Optima Prone's head-to-toe pressure alternation, mechanical apparatus for assisting single-caregiver head repositioning, personalized pressure care with individual air cell deflation, and a unique facial pillow with sculpted ear pocket reduces caregiver workload and risks of pressure injuries, improving patient outcomes.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.answer: Deflation should follow the location of the patient's vulnerable areas. Our recommendations are:

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

title: Optima Prone Fake32
description:
Alternating pressure redistribution system — Simplify procedure and workload for administering pressure relief care and pressure ulcer prevention.
Optima Auto provides caregivers more control and personalization over air mattress firmness, an elementary air pump interface suitable for all levels of caregivers, and a backup power system for maintaining pressure distribution up to 6 hours. Preventing pressure injuries improves patient outcomes and patient care experience.
Proned and intubated COVID-19 patients undergo prone treatments for an average of 5 hospital days. However, as proning results in a higher risk of developing pressure injuries (PI), these patients may require 3 more hospital days to treat PI-related complications,3,4 reducing the nurse-to-patient ratio further.5

title: Domus Auto Fake41
description:
Automating prone shoulder lifting and full-body pressure relief — Reducing workflow complexity and pressure injury risks.
Reducing pressure injuries for long-term care — Increasing skin activity and improving blood circulation with alternating pressure.
On average, 65 per 1000 adult inpatients develop pressure injuries (also known as pressure ulcers) and require 18 in-hospital days. That's 2.5 times that of an average acute inpatient. Financially, treating PU sets families back by USD 15,700 to USD 17,700. Since 87% are elderly patients, an ageing population and COVID-19 accelerates PU prevalence, exhausting global human, material, and capital reserves.

overviews.title: Prevent Pressure Injury Risks
overviews.description: Combining a unique headrest (facial pillow, sculpted ear pocket, and alternation pressure), a personalized pressure care system (individual air cell deflation), and cell airflow tracking prevents pressure injury risks, improving patient outcomes.

introductions.title: Manage Airway & Fluid Tubing
introductions.description: Deflating individual air cells to guide proper airway and fluid tubing organization prevents potential obstructions or displacements to hemodialysis flow and catheters, reducing the burden on the caregiver's workflow.

introductions.title: Improve Experience for Compliance
introductions.description: SleepWell allows care providers to provide patients with data-driven suggestions and treatment plans on-demand, increasing the patient's confidence and adherence in the first 90 days, critical for improving long-term therapy compliance.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: How long does Head Repositioning Mode's shoulder lifting assistance last?
faq.answer: Caregivers have 10 minutes to reposition the patient's head while the mechanical apparatus assists in lifting the shoulders and chest upward. After 10 minutes, the mode automatically deactivates and returns to initial settings. Caregivers can cancel anytime during the procedure through the pump's interface.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

introductions.title: Manage Airway & Fluid Tubing
introductions.description: Deflating individual air cells to guide proper airway and fluid tubing organization prevents potential obstructions or displacements to hemodialysis flow and catheters, reducing the burden on the caregiver's workflow.

introductions.title: Simplify Head Repositioning
introductions.description: Mechanically supporting shoulder lifts while creating space below the patient's chin decreases the caregiver's workload and risk of obstructing airway tubing, allowing the single-caregiver to perform head repositioning safely and efficiently.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: After selecting the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode, there is a 20-minute wait for the surface to reach max firmness. Will automatic detection be active during this time?
faq.answer: No. During this time, the Automatic Pressure Adjustment is inactive and will not be detecting the patient's weight.

faq.question: How does Optima Prone allow a single-caregiver to complete head repositioning during prone positioning therapies?
faq.answer: In addition to lifting and supporting the patient's shoulder and chest upwards, the Shoulder Lifting Mode also deflates the area below the patient's chin, creating space for the caregiver to secure a steady hold and turn the head while safely managing and preventing airway tubing obstructions.

faq.question: Any recommendations on the number of cells to deflate for each section and for heel relief?
faq.answer: Deflation should follow the location of the patient's vulnerable areas. Our recommendations are:

faq.question: Does it automatically switch to alternating pressure after the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode finishes?
faq.answer: Yes. Alternating pressure will automatically take over once the Supine Position Mode or Prone Position Mode deactivates after 20 minutes of operation.

faq.question: What materials are the air cells made from?
faq.answer: All air cells are made from Thermoplastic Polyurethanes (TPU). It is highly resistant to breaking down when in contact with water (hydrolysis), soft to touch, and minimizes friction and noise during patient movements.

faq.question: What does it mean when air cells have cell-in-cell? What are their benefits?
faq.answer: Cell-in-cell design refers to encapsulating a firm air cell within a larger outer cell, doubling the effect of firmness and stability for patients. Wellell’s Optima Series, including Prone, uses air cells with the cell-in-cell design in the sacrum area to improve patient support and comfort during sitting positions and when patients leave and enter the bed.

faq.question: What does the Shoulder Lifting Mode do?
faq.answer: The Shoulder Lifting Mode activates a mechanical apparatus that lifts and holds the patient's shoulders and chest upward, mimicking traditional prone positioning therapy's manual shoulder lifting procedure done by two or more caregivers. The lift helps release neck pressure that often leads to hyperextension injury and avoid spinal deformity body pains.

faq.question: What happens if the number of deflated cells exceeds the recommended setting?
faq.answer: Aside from deflating individual cells to relieve pressure on the patient's vulnerable areas, caregivers can do the same but, with less intensity, for other body parts like the abdominal area, which is often protruding and easy to experience discomfort.
